docs.lead_paragraph: A Federal health group wants 11 Western states with a high incidence of hepatitis A to require that children be vaccinated. Children are one of the highest risk groups for hepatitis A, an advisory committee on immunization for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta said last week.

headline.main: Hepatitis A Vaccinations Urged for Children in 11 Western States

docs.lead_paragraph: A review of medical studies linking religious faith to an improved prognosis for patients found little empirical support for claims, according to an article in the current issue of the medical journal Lancet. ''Even in the best studies, the evidence of an association between religion, spirituality and health is weak and inconsistent,'' concluded Dr. Richard P. Sloan, director of behavioral medicine at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York. ''We believe therefore that it is premature to promote faith and religion as adjunctive medical treatments.''

headline.main: Religious Faith and a Patient's Prognosis

docs.lead_paragraph: Getting rid of head lice used to be a straightforward affair. An insecticidal shampoo or rinse was slathered on the hair at night, and the lice were gone the next morning. But that has changed in the last few years, with the pest that is scientifically known as Pediculus humanus capitis showing resistance to standard remedies. Now, children are missing days, even weeks, of school because they cannot get rid of head lice. ''I know of kids who've been left back because they missed two months of school,'' said Terri Lynn Meinking, an assistant professor of dermatology at the University of Miami.

headline.main: As Lice Resist Treatment, the Battle Escalates

docs.lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, treadmills have exploded in popularity, and technology has sped along at a clip. And if several new models unveiled at the recent sporting goods extravaganza -- the Super Show in Atlanta -- are any indication, treadmills may soon do everything but the running. The Pro Form CD Coach, for example, has a CD player built into its console. The treadmill comes with an interactive CD that contains two 30-minute workout programs designed by certified personal trainers. Digital impulses from the CD soundtrack automatically adjust the speed and incline of the treadmill to coincide with the workout. The machine is available only at Sears, Roebuck & Company and sells for about $1,000.

headline.main: Upgrades on the Trail to Nowhere

docs.abstract: New and improved features are added to treadmills; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: I recently scheduled a long-overdue operation that could have been readily carried out in a doctor's office or in a hospital on an outpatient basis. It was nothing serious, but even so, my elderly mother begged me not to rush home because I lived alone. Instead, she urged me to remain in the hospital overnight, in case I needed attention. It's not possible, I argued, explaining with a hint of cynicism that procedures have become so sophisticated and coverage so restrictive that, in all but the most serious cases, patients are supposed to climb right off the operating table and march out the door. Try anyway, she admonished, ''just so I won't sit here worrying.''
docs.abstract: Medical hotels and post-operative recovery centers serve people who are having outpatient surgery but who cannot or prefer not to return home immediately; Louis F Reuter 4th, executive vice president of New York Presbyterian Hospital, which its considering a hotel at its Washington Heights complex, notes these kinds of centers are proliferating to meet changing patterns of patient care; photos of guest residence at Mount Sinai (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Siblings are fighting as much as ever, but many parents are letting them go at it, according to a new study that appears in the current issue of the American Psychological Association's journal, Developmental Psychology. In a study of 88 two-parent, two-sibling households, with children ages 3 to 9, the researchers asked the parents to describe strategies they used to resolve sibling conflicts and which strategies they felt confident using.

docs.lead_paragraph: Chances are your medicine chest is well stocked with first aid supplies to help you cope with the myriad injuries that sooner or later befall every man, woman and child -- Band-Aids, bite and burn ointments, cold packs, perhaps even a first-aid manual. But what have you got for your dog? In most households, this beloved member of the family, even if regularly groomed, carefully trained and fed a specially formulated diet, is sorely neglected when it comes to first aid.

headline.main: Being Dog's Best Friend When Trauma Strikes

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on providing first aid for one's pet dog when trauma strikes; drawings illustrate how to restrain an injured dog (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Charles Gerba's office is plastered with photographs of parasites and bacteria; his file drawers are full of antibacterial soaps and disinfectants. The counters of his lab are littered with petri dish samples from various public spaces in Tucson, where he is a professor of microbiology at the University of Arizona. He speaks with reverence of Cloacina, the long-forgotten Roman goddess of the sewer, and hands a visitor a biography of Thomas Crapper, inventor of the flush toilet, saying, ''He doesn't get nearly enough respect.'' For Dr. Gerba, 53, all roads lead back to the toilet. A bearded, fidgety man in yellow tinted glasses and blue jeans, he has spent the last two decades ferreting out where bacteria lurk in our daily lives. But for much of that time, his interest in the bathroom went unnoticed. Dr. Gerba is best known in his field of environmental microbiology for his work in uncovering how viruses infiltrate drinking water, and has consulted for American cities and other countries on how to improve water quality.

headline.main: On Germ Patrol, at the Kitchen Sink

docs.abstract: Profile of Dr Charles Gerba, professor of microbiology at University of Arizona who has built a career tracking down parasites and bacteria in bathrooms and kitchens; Gerba is best known in his field of environmental microbiology for his work in uncovering how viruses infiltrate drinking water; Gerba's latest project is the laundry, task he believes Americans regard with not nearly enough caution or diligence; photo (M)
